title: Upper Limb Nerve Lesions — Slide Highlights
summary: Key slide deck takeaways for radial, median, and ulnar lesions plus plexus patterns.
high_yield: Radial nerve distal arm lesion → wrist drop + dorsal hand sensory loss.
Median lesion: CTS starts with sensory loss; thenar weakness appears later.
Ulnar lesion at elbow → radial deviation on wrist flexion (FCU denervated).
Superior plexus (C5–C6) affects suprascapular, axillary, musculocutaneous.
pitfalls: Don't confuse dermatomes (root-level) with cutaneous peripheral nerve maps.

content.stem: Which primary motor deficit is expected with a distal radial nerve lesion?

choices.text: Loss of wrist and digit extension (wrist drop)

rationale.correct: Radial motor fibers innervate wrist/digit extensors; distal lesions produce wrist drop.
